North Africa Through The Ages

The First Punic War

200 B.C.E. - 1200 C.E.

Mansa Musa

1300 - 1350 C.E.

Mansa Musa's Pilgrimage to Mecca

1324 C.E.

Barbary Slave Trade

1500 - 1700 C.E.

Algerian Resistance Against France

1850 - 1900 C.E.

Senussi War

1915 - 1921 C.E.

North African Campaign During WWII

1940 - 1943 C.E.

Algerian War

1954 - 1962 C.E.

Primary Source

“The Carthaginians shall evacuate the whole of Sicily: they shall not make war upon Hiero, nor bear arms against the Syracusans or their allies. The Carthaginians shall give up to the Romans all prisoners without ransom. The Carthaginians shall pay to the Romans in twenty years 2200 Euboic talents of silver.”

- Polybius

Secondary Source

The First Punic War was fought between Ancient Carthage and the Roman Republic over the islands Siciliy and Corsica. Ancient Carthage was an empire in Northern African, while the Roman Republic was a civilization centered around the Italian peninsula. Scicily and Corisca were strategic locations and each empire wanted to control those. It originally belonged to Ancient Carthage, but the Romans won the war and took over them.

- Britannica

Meanwhile

  • The Persian Empire reaches its height, and then starts to fall due to internal and external factors.
  • The Roman Republic becomes the Roman Empire.
  • Julius Caesar forms the triumvirate, becomes sole dictator, and gets assassinated.
  • The Indian Empire spreads and Hinduism becomes the religion instead of Buddhism.
  • The Chinese dynasties each contribute to a unique part of ancient China.
  • The Mongols gain lots of territory, spread their influence, and become one of the most powerful empires in the world.

Overview

At the time of the First Punic War, the majority of Northern Africa was controlled by the Carthaginian Empire. Ancient Carthage was led by a monarchy until its demise. Ancient Carthage's main rival was the Roman Republic, with whom they had many conflicts. Ancient Carthage dominated the North African region by its military, trade connections, and economy.

Primary Source

The image depicts the ninth leader of the Mali Empire, Mansa Musa, holding an Imperial Golden Globe in the 1375 Catlan Atlas (description source).

- BlackPast

Secondary Source

Mansa Musa was the ninth leader of the Mali empire. The Mali Empire was already prosperous and powerful, and Mansa Musa helped the empire reach its peak. Mansa Musa is most famous for his pilgrimage to Mecca. The pilgrminage drew international attention to the Mali Empire, and made its power well known. He also became known worldwide after.

- Britannica

Meanwhile

  • Rome falls and the Roman Empire splits into Western and Eastern halves.
  • Byzantium, the Eastern part of the Roman Empire, prospers and becomes a center of economic and social growth.
  • The Middle Ages start in Europe, literacy rates drop, and the Church becomes very powerful.
  • Like Europe, feudalism also emerges in Japan, though with some key differences in principles.
  • The Islamic Empires, most notably the Ottoman Empire, grew powerful and spread across the Middle East, North Africa, and Southeast Europe.
  • The Crusades begin, which causes many deaths, economic instability, and many international problems.
  • The Bubonic Plague ravages Europe causing a change in society and cultural norms.
  • The Hundred Years war happens, an important event in the Britain and France conflict.

Overview

Governments at this time were mostly monarchies, and those in North Africa, were heavily influenced by Islam. From Mansa Musa to the Ottoman rulers, Islam was at the core of the empires. Society was distributed by socioeconomic factors with a wide range of professions. Larger, mor established empires were relatively peacefule, while prospective ones, less so.

Primary Source

The image shows important events and places along Mansa Musa's pilgrimage route.

- Britannica

Secondary Source

Mansa Musa, a Muslim, made a pilgrimage to Mecca. As a result of this journey, Mansa Musa would be widely known for his wealth and the Mali Empire for its power and size. Mansa Musa travelled with tens of thousands of people and dozens of camels, each carrying 300 pounds of gold. Mansa Musa then distributed the gold to people he saw on his journey, causing the price of gold to drop in Egypt for a while.

- National Geographic

Meanwhile

  • Gaps in social and government structures bring in the Renaissance, a period of scientific innovations, thinking, and inventions.
  • Italy becomes the center of development in Europe.
  • Martin Luther begins the Protestant reformation movement.
  • Power of the Catholic Church greatly decreases.
  • Education becomes more widespread in Europe.
  • European countries start exploring the New World and other regions.
  • The Columbian Exchange and the Atlantic Slave Trade take place.

Overview

Mansa Musa was the ruler who helped the Mali Empire reach its peak. After his pilgrimage, Mansa Musa "revitalized" Mali by emphasizing education especially for Islamic studies. He built universities, mosques, and improved architecture. This "revitalization" spread across North Africa, making the region prosperous and peaceful. Apart from the Mali Empire and Egypt, much of Northern Africa was made up of small tribes whose economies and militaries did not affect the region in any major way.

Primary Source

The image depicts how the Barbary Slave trade would look like, with the enslaved, the enslavers, and the buyers.

- Wikimedia

Secondary Source

The Barbary Slave Trade was a organized slave capturing operation by Barbary pirates who captured slaves to sell in the Arab slave markets in North Africa. Not only were Africans captured by the priates, European men and women (mostly English) were also taken. European leaders tried unsuccessfully to stop the pirates, but resorted to ransom payments. The priates, though, continued to capture Africans.

- National Geographic

Meanwhile

  • The Scientific Revolution begins and many past ideas are debunked in place of new, scientifically proven ones.
  • The Enlightenment begins and philosophers and their philosophies become widely accepted in hand with science.
  • The English Revolution occurs, which limits the English Monarchy’s power.
  • The American Revolution occurs and the colonies become independent. England loses a key resource giving colony.
  • The French Revolution occurs after the Third Estate gets angry at the unfair taxes levied on them.
  • Looking at France and America, many Latin American countries also fought for, and got, their independence.

Overview

Northern Africa was stable and the empires controlling parts of it were prospering. Because of this economic growth, slaves came into a high demand. Other parts of Africa, especially coastal ones to the South were controlled by small tribes, who were easily overpowered by pirates. Overall, the economic and social power laid in the North, while the South was still having tribal warfares.

Primary Source

The image shows how the Battle of Smala, a key turning point in the movement against France, would have looked.

- Wikimedia

Secondary Source

The French were not very popular among most Algerians, so Algerian nationalist movements had began against the colonizers. The French and Algerians had many military engagements, and the results were mixed. In the end, France kept control, but Aglerians had proven that they could resist. In addition, fighting between the Algerians and the French allowed for some tribes along the Algerian border to break away, causing more problems for France.

- Britannica

Meanwhile

  • The Industrial Revolution began after inventions to automate hard tasks and resources to power those inventions became mainstream.
  • Capitalism, Socialism, and Communism started and most governments were modeled after one of them.
  • Europe, with its new technology, aggressively colonized places in order to get more resources.
  • Imperialism, mainly that of Britain, caused harm and good in its colonies. British Imperialism brought new technologies, medical care, and education to the colonies, but the British also oppressed the native people.
  • America starts spreading in the Pacific, Caribbean, and Central America.

Overview

At the time, North Africa was controlled by European powers. European colonialism changed many aspects of society in North Africa. From Europeans demanding more resources from the colonies, to lack of societal autonomy, North Africa was in the hands of Europe and its people were ont happy. Nationalist movements had begun against the colonizers, but non would bear fruit till much later. Local leaders would break away from European controlled territories and start their own tribes, whose support would be critical for Europeans to gain control of North Africa.

Primary Source

The image shows British soldiers in Libya, where the majority of the fighting took place.

- National Army Museum

Secondary Source

The Senussi War was a military conflict between the Senussi and Britain. The Senussi were a relatively peaceful religious sect of the Sahara Dessert who were friendly with the British in Egypt. The Turks persuaded the Senussi to attack Britain. The result was a loss for the Senussi and a change in leadership. The war gave Britain more territory around Egypt, which enabled them to have multiple successes in the WWI North African Theater.

- History of War

Meanwhile

  • WWI starts and brings in complex alliances, new battlefields in and around Europe, and new hostilities.
  • The League of Nations is created.
  • Germany is hit hard with reparations and post-war restrictions.
  • World leaders are working towards peace.

Overview

WWI was going on and the British had established a presence in Northern Africa. The Ottoman Empire, an enemy of the British, sought to stop the British from moving into North Africa. The British had establishments in Egypt, so the Ottoman Empire was afraid as present-day Turkey, their homeland, was near by. Regarding the governmental situation, colonies in North Africa were still present, but tribes and small nations started to form. These small nations either were peaceful, allied with a WWI power, or were warring for territory.

Primary Source

The image shows American soldiers on their way to battle in the North African Campaign of WWII.

- Wikipedia

Secondary Source

The North African Campaign of WWII was a series of battles in North Africa between the Allies and Axis that would decide who was in charge of the Suez Canal, a vital waterway, and the vast, vauable Middle Eastern oil reserves. The battles were primarily fought by Britain and France vs Germany and Italy. If the Allies controlled North Africa, Italy was easy to target. Likewise, if the Axis controlled North Africa, then France would be easily taken over.

- Britannica

Meanwhile

  • The Great Depression rocks the economic state of the world.
  • WWII starts and it proves to be worse than WWI. Battlefields are not only in Europe and the surrounding areas, but are there globally. Newer weapons cause more destruction to many parts of the world.
  • The UN is created.
  • Once again, world leaders try to work towards peace.

Overview

WWII had just started and both sides, Allies and Axis, were eager to control as much territory in and around Europe, as possible. Frequent battles, not only in Europe, but th surrounding areas as well, meant that stability was rare. In North Africa, coexisting tribes were now forced to choose sides and battle. Society was not progressing, rather, people were more focused on either their safety or the victory of their tribe and European partner. Colonies were mostly gone, but the borders drawn by the Europeans caused hostilities between tribal neighbors.

Primary Source

The image shows French soldiers in Algeria during the Algerian War

- Foreign Policy

Secondary Source

The Algerian War was a series of battles between Algerian rebels and France. The Algerian rebels mostly resorted to guerilla warfare, which proved effective against the French. The French, in order to retain control of Algeria, used brutal tactics to subdue the population. The cost and lack of political will in the war resulted in a victory for the Algerians. Most of the war was fought in harsh terrain and poor conditions. The civillian deaths were also high as both sides targeted cities and towns.

- Britannica

Meanwhile

  • The Cold War between the US and USSR begins.
  • Proxy wars such as those in Afghanistan are fought.
  • The US tries to contain Communism, while the USSR tries to spread it.
  • The Space Race begins as each country tries to gain spaceflight superiority.
  • The Arms Race, for nuclear weapons, begins and mutually assured destruction becomes a constant threat.
  • The Bay of Pigs invasion and Cuban Missile Crisis also happened.
  • The USSR moves towards a more free social, political, economic structure
  • The Berlin Wall falls marking the end of the Cold War

Overview

The economic state of the world at this time was substandard as WWII had just finsihed. European powers lost their military and financial power, which led colonies to rebel and seek freedom. This was especially true in North Africa as many regions were controlled or affiliated to an European power. Due to these connections, the general population formed rebel groups to fight against oppressing tribes or nations. The social state, like WWII, was fight or flight, without much progress in any field.

by Gautam Pradhan • source code here
